abstract.p: An explicit method is derived for collocating either of the convolution integrals p(x) = ∫<sup>x</sup><sub>a</sub> f(x - t)g(t) dt or q(x) = ∫<sup>b</sup><sub>x</sub> f(t - x)g(t)dt, where x ∈ (a, b), a subinterval of R. The collocation formulas take the form p = F(A<sub>m</sub>)g or q = F(B<sub>m</sub>)g, where g is an m-vector of values of the function g evaluated at the "Sinc points", A<sub>m</sub> and B<sub>m</sub> are explicitly described square matrices of order m, and F(s) = ∫<sup>c</sup><sub>0</sub> exp[ -t/s] f(t)dt, for arbitrary c ∈ [(b - a), ∞]. The components of the resulting vectors p (resp., q) approximate the values of p (resp., q) at the Sinc points, and may then be used in a Sinc interpolation formula to approximate p and q at arbitrary points on (a, b). The procedure offers a new method of approximating the solutions to (definite or indefinite) convolution-type integrals or integral equations as well as solutions of partial differential equations that are expressed in terms of convolution-type integrals or integral equations via the use of Green's functions. If u is the solution of a partial differential equation expressed as a ν-dimensional convolution integral over a rectangular region B, and if u is analytic and of class Lip<sub>α</sub> on the interior of each line segment in B, then the complexity of computing an ε-approximation of u by the method of this paper is O([(log(ε)]<sup>2ν + 2</sup>).
